topic.title: Data
topic.shortdesc: Couchbase Server saves data as items, each of which has a key and a value.

section.title: Items, Keys, and Values
section.p: Each item consists of a key and a value. Each key is unique, within its bucket. Its value can be either binary or JSON.

section.title: Keys
section.p: Each value (binary or JSON) is identified by a unique key. A key may be custom-created (for example, at the UI of Couchbase Web Console); or it may be generated by an application, possibly using a programmatic counter or UUID generator. A key is immutable: once defined, it cannot be changed.
Note that Couchbase also refers to an item's key as its id.

ul.li: Must be a UTF-8 string with no spaces. Special characters, such as (, %, /, ", and _, are acceptable.
May be no longer than 250 bytes.
Must be unique within its bucket.

section.title: Values
section.p: The maximum size of a value is 20 MB. A value can be either:

ul.li: Binary: Any form of binary is acceptable. Note that a binary cannnot be parsed, indexed, or queried.

JSON: A JSON value, referred to as a document, can be parsed, indexed, and queried. Each document consists of one or more attributes, each of which has its own value. An attribute's value can be a basic type, such as a number, string, or Boolean; or a complex, such as an embedded document, or an array.

section.title: Document Structure
section.p: A sample JSON document is provided immediately below. Its contents are as follows:

ul.li: a1 and a2 are attributes that respectively have a single number and a single string as their values.
a3 is an attribute whose value is an embedded document consisting of a single attribute, b1, whose own value is an array of three numbers.
a4 is an attribute whose value is an array of two documents, each document consisting of attributes (c1, c2) each of whose values is a number.

section.p: Note that the official JSON definition is provided at RFC 7159, and at ECMA 404.
The benefits offered to application-programmers by JSON are considered in The Couchbase Data Model.

section.title: Sub-Documents
section.p: A sub-document is an inner component of a JSON document. The sub-document is referred to by a path, which specifies attributes and array-positions.
From, the example given above, the following paths are among those that can be specified.

ul.li: a1, whose value is a number
a3.b1, whose value is an array of numbers
a3.b1[0], whose value is the first number in an array
a4[1].c2, whose value is a number

section.p: The Couchbase SDK provides a Sub-Document API, which allows paths to be specified, and sub-documents thereby read and written to. This makes it unnecessary to transfer entire documents over the network when only partial modifications are required, potentially providing significant improvements in network-performance. For further information, see Sub-Document Operations.

section.title: Meta-Data
section.p: Meta-data is automatically generated and stored for each item saved in Couchbase Server. For example, consider the following document, which contains airport-information, and has been saved with the key airport_1306:
Couchbase Server generates meta-data in association with the document, when the document is saved. The meta-data might be as follows:
The attributes within the meta-data are:

ul.li: meta: The attribute whose value is the standard meta-data document for the saved document, airport-1306.
id: The key of the saved document, which is airport_1306.

rev: The revision or sequence number. This value is for internal server-use only: it is used in the resolution of conflicts that occur when replicated documents are updated concurrently on different servers, representing the number of times the document has been mutated. For more information on conflict resolution, see Timestamp-based Conflict Resolution.

expiration: The expiration-time (or Time-To-Live) of the document. If non-zero, this determines the point at which the document is removed from the system. The value can be set in either of two ways: per-document, by means of Couchbase SDK APIs (which is referred to as TTL); or per bucket, by means of Couchbase SDK APIs, the Couchbase Web Console, the Couchbase CLI, or the Couchbase REST API (which is referred to as Bucket TTL).
For information on TTL, see Core Operations. For information on Bucket TTL, see Bucket TTL.
flags: Couchbase SDK-specific values that may be used to identify the type of data saved, or to specify formatting.
type: The type of the saved value, which in this case is json.

xattrs: Extended Attributes, which constitute a special kind of metadata, some of which is server-internal, some of which can optionally be written and read by user-applications. See Extended Attributes for more information.
